summary: This is a letter from defense counsel Jeffrey S. Pagliuca to the U.S. Attorney's Office objecting to the government's proffered co-conspirator hearsay statements in the case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The letter argues certain categories of statements are not made during or in furtherance of the alleged conspiracy and should be excluded.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, against whom the government is seeking to admit co-conspirator hearsay statements.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman representing Ghislaine Maxwell, authoring this letter of objection to the prosecution's proffered evidence.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as the alleged co-conspirator; the letter objects to statements he made to employees and others, arguing they are not in furtherance of the conspiracy.

connections.description: The government alleges they conspired together; the defense is objecting to statements between them and others as hearsay.
Pagliuca is defense counsel filing objections on behalf of Maxwell.

events.title: Court Order on Hearsay
events.description: The Court issued an order, likely regarding procedures for objecting to co-conspirator hearsay statements.

events.title: Government Correspondence on Victims
events.description: The government sent correspondence to defense counsel identifying specific 'minor victims' relevant to the case.

locations: United States Attorney's Office Southern District of New York, 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C., 150 East 10th Avenue, Denver, CO
keyFacts: Defense counsel objects to categories of alleged co-conspirator hearsay statements, arguing they lack temporal limitations or were made outside the conspiracy.
The defense specifically challenges statements from Epstein to employees, like one where Epstein claimed Maxwell 'used to find girls for him,' as 'idle chatter' not in furtherance of the conspiracy.
The letter references 'CC-1' and 'CC-2' as co-conspirators, indicating the government has identified other alleged conspirators beyond Epstein and Maxwell.
The defense seeks to limit 'minor victim' statements to only those individuals specifically identified by the government in its October 11, 2021 correspondence.
